awd_titl_txt: I-Corps: Revealing the dynamics of online crowds through many-body analysis
awd_abstract_narration:
The broader impact/commercial potential of this I-Corps project is to provide a better understanding of the online world. Specifically, it enables potential commercial applications in market sectors across countries and languages. The technology is built entirely from publicly accessible information, without the need for any individual information.  The potential applications include companies requiring a better understanding of the existing user/fan base and opponents of its particular products, marketing companies looking to better understand market sectors, companies in healthcare looking to understand attitudes toward treatments, and corporations interested in assessing global risk. The technology goes well beyond current practices and techniques in social listening and surveys.

This I-Corps project connects and combines ideas on many-body behaviors in the online world, together with advances in the science of networks of networks. The combination of these allows the core technology to provide a window into online crowd behaviors across multiple platforms and languages. The technology features an automated process of collecting together the online cluster information and then describing and forecasting its development. In this sense, it is a form of physics-inspired artificial intelligence. Instead of collections of particles, the system now comprises collections of heterogeneous online users. The focus is entirely on the overall ecology, in order to get at potential tipping points and shifts in market sentiment about a particular product, as well as the ebbs and flows in support of a given product's competition.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.
org_dir_long_name: Directorate for Technology, Innovation, and Partnerships

por.por_cntn:
The objective of the project was customer discovery surrounding new technology. This new technology is a new way of looking at the crowds that form online around particular topics, including products. It is a form of artificial intelligence supplemented by models from the team's published papers in the area of ‘many-body’ complex systems. Instead of collections of particles, they are now collections of heterogeneous online users. The focus is entirely on the overall ecology, in order to get at potential tipping points and shifts in market sentiment about a particular product, as well as the ebbs and flows in support of its competition. Hence it combines cross-disciplinary fundamental research with data science, to provide new actionable insights beyond standard methods and artificial intelligence (AI) approaches. 

The specific objective was customer discovery in person, since this is where the discussions become most relevant and useful. This was achieved well initially, both in the U.S. and internationally (specifically, within the financial sector in U.K. who have a particular interest in such alternative data). However, it could not continue during lockdown and because of the subsequent travel restrictions. The use of Zoom etc. for virtual meetings proved inadequate, since people being interviewed suspected they were being recorded etc. and would not let their guard down. 

Despite this, a key outcome success was the significant amount of training and professional development for members of the team. Each learned a lot from the initial customer discovery process that they could never have imagined before. The customer discovery led to many illuminating discussions with people in industry and business who had no idea about the technical field underlying the technology and what it might offer. We believe that there was significant educational exchange in terms of knowledge coming into the team and from the team to those being interviewed. In addition, those being interviewed were very interested to learn about NSF involvement and funding of this.


Last Modified: 12/16/2021
Modified by: Neil F Johnson
